item.title: Making Sense of Empowerment
item.dc:creator: Paul Johnston
item.content:encoded: Last night I was at the UK's Royal Society for the Encouragement of the Arts and took part in a fascinating discussion on empowerment, hosted by the RSA's chief executive Matthew Taylor and featuring an interesting contribution from the Chief Secretary to the Treasury Andy Burnham. What was particularly striking was the way each participant seemed to come at the debate from a different perspective. For some empowerment was about moving away from a consumerist approach to public services (with an emphasis on choice and improved delivery) to a perspective that encourages citizens to take more responsibility for their lives and to take ownership of “their” public services. For others, it was about moving away from central government command and control and empowering more local parts of the state and public servants within them. Not so much citizen empowerment as frontline public servant empowerment. One example that dominated the discussion were moves in the UK to give social care recipients direct control of the money being used to support them. That way recipients can determine the most appropriate blend and type of services to improve their situation. This was generally seen as a welcome move away from producer-led services and towards letting citizens build services that were genuinely citizen-centric. But while few wanted to oppose this step in social care (or at least for some fairly specific categories of social care recipient), there was quite a lot of discomfort about how far this sort of change could be generalized. Surely in some areas citizens did just want effective delivery rather than empowerment? And while some services could be co-produced with citizens (e.g. nursery or primary education?), more complex services (such as secondary education) might prove tougher for citizens to do for themselves. Although not explicitly mentioned, there were clearly some submerged political issues running beneath the debate in this area, since many of the participants in the debate came from what would traditionally be seen as a left-of-centre position and yet replacing public provision by giving the money to citizens and letting them choose their provider is traditionally a right-wing perspective. Disrupting producer power and abandoning one size fits all solutions sound great, but will that generate a multi-tiered service with those at the bottom of society getting a markedly inferior service in multiple areas of their lives? Can the state just to do some kind of financial redistribution and then stand out of the way and let whatever happens happen? Surprisingly, a lot of the talk did seem to be about financial empowerment, whereas I had been expecting the debate to focus more on the new scope for getting citizens much more involved in public sector decision-making. Tom Steinberg made the excellent point that there was a lot of mileage in just putting public service users in touch with each other. So if I have feedback on my local hospital, I do not just give the feedback to the hospital but am connected with others who have given feedback and all those taking an interest in how that hospital is run. I agree with Tom that this sort of simple move could be a powerful lever for change (especially if it is combined with transparency, so I can see all the other feedback the public sector organization has received). The other point this leads onto (which we did not really discuss) is individual empowerment vs community empowerment. How does empowerment work when it is going to generate a mass of conflicting choices and demands? So an amazingly complex agenda, but one that is deeply relevant in the UK where we have seen a government embrace command and control on a massive scale in the hope of delivering truly excellent public services (and long-living, happy citizens). Now there seems to be a recognition that things need to change, but we only seem to be at the beginning of the debate as to who should be empowered and how.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Great post and some really good issues raised here. It prompted some questions:
Why are empowerment and good quality public services seen as mutually exclusive choices?
Why do we assume that people on the lower end of the socio-economic scale won’t be able to negotiate, either themselves or with whatever support and advice they need, a service mix and outcome at least equal to, and perhaps superior to, anyone else?
Why do we start from the assumption that command-and-control, centralised public provision of public services actually provide equity and consistent quality ? Clearly they often do not, which is wny we labour so mightily to 'reform' public services in virtually every jurisdiction I know. This is despite the best intentions (and the ideological predisposition) of those who are responsible for designing and delivering them?
Why are ‘uneven’ public services necessarily wrong? Why does the notion of everyone getting exactly the same make sense anyway?
The notion that empowerment has to result in people actually running their own services is simplistic and misleading. It’s also a false dichtomomy perhaps set up by those seeking to preserve the status quo and anxious to avoid any change by suggesting that the only change available is to this relatively extreme position. Mind you, there are some great examples of people who do actually want to do it for themselves - setting up schools, impriving services for disabled people. I know of several here in Australia. But in many cases, the real empowerment that people want is not to run social welfatre or education servides (although in the education space, there’s plenty of evidence and a great deal of successful practice to suggest that is exactly what people want to do, and often can do much better than standaridsed, centralised public provision), but rather to inject some sense of power and control over the design, delivery and quality of the services they need. Noone suggests that consumer empowerment in the airline industry means everyone wants to run their own airline. For most people, except perhaps Richard Branson, what they want is a level of choice, influence and status as a customer to have a real impact on the quality, timeleness, safety etc of the services they want. I’m an empowered air traveler not because I run Qantas but because I have enough clout as a consumer to have an impact on the services they offer and, in the end, can chose to fly with someone else whose service bundle might better suit me and my needs.
There's a great piece of work I can post to the site from Australia looking at whole new approaches to disability services. The model is essentially an empowered consumer model. As the author, Vern Hughes, points out though, it's introduction would challenge central assumptions about powe, control and authority and, importantly, shift the focus away from those who supply services to those who demand them. Vern's model is all about giving those people the money and the authoirty to act as real consumers. Scary stuff and, of course, stoutly resisted by those whose interests are protected by the status quo.

item.title: Government 2.0 - Two Cheers for the Romantics - Final Part
item.dc:creator: Martin Stewart Weeks
item.content:encoded:
The whole session was titled ‘Government 2.0 – fad or future?’ So what did we conclude by the end of the discussion? I think we decided that government 2.0 was more future than fad, that a long-term, gradual and unstoppable revolution had started that would dramatically change the processes, structures and behaviour of governments and that by and large that was a very good thing. At the same time, we weren’t blind to the obvious obstacles that would provide plenty of opportunity for resistance and delay. Nor were people naïve enough to think that the entrenched cultures and structures of governing would be easy to shift. But what I took away from the discussion overall was a real sense of possibility and opportunity. With a mixture of excitement, realism and some trepidation, I felt that people were for the most part prepared to sign up for the ‘government 2.0’ revolution, largely in the end because the accumulating demographic and performance improvement imperatives impacting governments and their public management systems would prove, in the end, to be irresistible. I think people decide these questions in the end depending on whether they tend to be realists or romantics. In the end, I am a bit of both. The romantic in me sees the disruptive possibilities of these new technologies and the way they might refresh the vision and values of public management. The realist in me sees deep, structural resistance and massive opportunities for denial and delay from many who currently occupy the commanding heights of power and control and therefore whose personal and professional interests are most challenged by the potential for change. I think in the end they will lose, but it won’t be without a fight. Here are a few final points that were summarised by Hillingdon CIO Steve Palmer who was an active and very thoughtful participant in the Nobel discussions…
  • The Web 2.0 developments challenge leadership and the legitimacy of political roles, responsibilities and structures in uncomfortable ways. It also gives an opportunity for "true" democracy - a possibly scary possibility to those who hold or enjoy power under the old rules.
  • There is a need to be open, honest and transparent in what issues we are properly prepared to engage communities/people in making decisions upon. Where do we want genuine engagement (web 2.0) may work in shaping? Where to want real or pretend consultation (web 2.0 may work). For the "no go" areas it won't work but what are the consequences of governments deciding not to engage - web 2.0 can be used to create very collaborative opposition.
  • The technologies are benign, the content provides the stimulus. What are the consequences of failure to mesh what can be perceived as revolutionary technologies with the business of government?
  • There is a huge opportunity however to generate well informed, genuine innovation and engagement at community level including providing some added opportunities to develop true social innovation.
  • We need to accept there is disconnect between the methods of collaboration, communication and aspiration of emerging generations against antiquated workplaces, workstyle and work based technologies.

item.title: Empowering the Poor
item.dc:creator: Molly Tschang
item.content:encoded:
Empowerment was a key theme during our December 10, 2007 “Socially Inclusive Growth” specialist session at Cisco's Public Services Summit. The topic was economic development and social inclusion of the poor, highlighting three project that are both scalable and sustainable. Below I share some of our dialogue around empowerment, a few compelling on-the-ground impacts and chime in on what Paul raised re: who should be empowered and how; citizen, community, and financial empowerment.
“Empowerment” seems a basic term — generally, governments, NGOs, private sector support “empowering the poor,” yet it can be elusive to actually achieve.
In the context of emerging regions, one description of citizen empowerment is “having access to information to make informed decisions about improving one’s own life and opportunities to do so.” One notion we put forth is that the problem is “the people are poor, not stupid.”
While few would disagree, the challenge is whether programs are designed to tap into the capabilities of the people to improve their own lives. Frequently, organizations (whether gov’t, civil society or private sector) try perhaps to do more than they should, thereby disempowering targeted beneficiaries.
Case in point, we reviewed in some detail a national poverty alleviation program that’s being implemented in Sri Lanka. The Gemidiriya (meaning Village Empowerment) model was developed by the World Bank and poor communities, starting in 2000 with a 3-village pilot. The formal scale-up started in 2004.
Empowerment is an essential success factor to this community driven development (CDD) program, which will reach 1,000 rural villages (1M Sri Lankans) by end of 2007 and has a target of 5,000-8,000 add’l villages in the next few years. These villages have ~1,000 people and are among the poorest of the poor.
The Gemidiriya success is rooted building strong village governance. The approach helps villagers create a “Village Organization” enabling the community to come together to discuss issues, prioritize their work, and allocate funds (Yes – they must contribute to projects. In a recent call we reiterated that in successful dev. projects the poor contribute – whether cash, labor or combination). There are formal boards and committees, and women hold 50% of decision-making positions, and youth (ages 16-35), 30%. These Village Organizations tap into the full talent base, and with access to combination of grant and loan funding, the communities have solved for the most urgent infrastructure needs – water, sanitation, roads, small bridges.
For Gemidiriya, the elements of individual and community empowerment are not “either/or,” but rather “and.”
In particular, to look into the eyes of women – elder and youth – it is palpable how much the opportunity for individual empowerment and voice within the community is valued. While I was in the field observing groups discuss needs, they clearly understood the need to solve community interests, while also care for those least able to do so. The Gemidiriya communities are bound by a set of “10 Golden Rules” (Unity, Self-Esteem, Accountability, Trust, Realism, Thrift, Transparency, Equality, Consensus, Sincerity). These shared values are 200% internalized in every interaction and decision. Empowerment brings with it responsibility and Gemidiriya poor communities understand and exemplify this, perhaps in some cases better than developed areas.
The communities decide on and manage execution of the projects (e.g., vendor selection, type of system, follow-on support). As communities “graduate,” they form a “Village Company” focused on improving livelihoods. These Companies have formed partnerships with private sector, attracting investment from leading national and multinational business agencies, including a commitment of $10 million from National Dairy Development Board, India.
In a given village, “community professionals” emerge as those who are leading the change for their community. These CPs (think of them as internal consultants who may specialize in water, sanitation, facilitation, etc.) then are paid by other villages to assist their implementation. A chief reason for the successful scaling lies in Sri Lankans helping Sri Lankans (not relying on bringing in more and more external World Bank staff or others).
Key areas of impact with government include: • The Government of Sri Lanka has been the entity to decide “who was poor” and “who were the poorest of the poor” and what benefits to provide. This did not result in well targeted, effective programs. In Gemidiriya, the communities determine who are most needy, and great care is focused on serving the most vulnerable. This is influencing the government’s policy for targeting. • In succeeding with infrastructure projects, communities have built up confidence of their capabilities and their collective voice to interact with local gov’t. They’ve begun to speak with local officials and are tapping into streams of available gov’t funding, thereby decreasing reliance on World Bank funds. Local officials see Gemidiriya as a way to previously unreached, unheard from constituents. • This holistic, empowerment model has been chosen for the government’s national poverty reduction program (a similar approach was in progress and they’ve decided to converge on the Gemidiriya metholodogy.
Stay tuned, we’re now endeavoring to apply the success of CDD to help villagers benefit from ICT – creating bottom-up momentum for ICT to improve livelihoods.
Perhaps it can be easier to “start empowerment from scratch” vs. dissect the conflicting choices and demands of a UK. Though places like the UK may indeed learn from the Gemidiriya example of functioning communities, which abide by the 10 Golden Rules and can raise tough issues, discuss, prioritize needs and solve for their most pressing needs.

Great story - a good reminder of the famous observation that the only thing that's different between the rich and the poor is that the rich have got more money!
Which suggests that the key to success is to find ways to get more money and assets into the hands of poor communities so they can start the normal wealth creation cycle that everyone else relies on.
The governance piece is obviously important too, as Molly's story suggests. item.title: Goodbye to Consumerism, hello to Produsage?
item.dc:creator: Paul Johnston
item.content:encoded: Australian academic Axel Bruns has just launched a website (soon to be followed by a book) where he celebrates the new era of “produsage” – the idea being that in certain collaborative communities “the creation of shared content takes place in a networked, participatory environment which breaks down the boundaries between producers and consumers and instead enables all participants to be users as well as producers of information and knowledge - frequently in a hybrid role of produser where usage is necessarily also productive.”. There are a lot of interesting ideas on the site, although personally I doubt whether the phrase “produsage” is going to be a smash hit. I also rather fear that production and consumerism are both likely to continue to dominate most people’s lives (indeed, are likely to dominate the lives of increasing numbers of people as China, India, etc continue to grow rapidly). Axel talks about the principles and preconditions of produsage, but I am not sure I agree with all of his analysis and it is quite complicated (and for me sometimes a bit confusing). Here’s my take on what he is talking about. We are definitely seeing the emergence of a new form of value creation. The precondition of which are network technologies that enable large-scale many-to-many communication. In contrast to traditional value creation based on the interaction of hierarchical organisations, in this emerging model value is created by self-organising virtual communities. Participation is as open as possible and the status of participants is determined on a dynamic, real-time basis by their contribution (as assessed by the community) rather than by who they are (their organisational role/job title etc). The value creation process moves forward probabilistically rather than on a linear or planned basis – quality comes from the number and diversity of the people engaged on the task rather than top-down enforcement of a pre-given plan or strategy. Everyone’s contribution is fully and permanently open to view, so all members of the community have the same ability to assess how the project is progressing. The value created is available to all (including non active participants) but active participants do get individual rewards either in terms of the satisfaction or status gained from participating in the value-generating community or because there are spin-off benefits from participation. Generally, this approach works best where tasks are granular, i.e. can easily be split up into small elements that can be worked up separately. (Conversely, this approach is not the best way to write a novel – although I know (unsuccessful) attempts to do just this have been made!). For me the really interesting issue is mapping out where this new approach will work best and why. I certainly think it has got limits, but I also think that since it is new, there must be zillions of areas where applying it could be really useful. So those are Axel’s points that hit home with me. Apologies to him if I have distorted them and for the many points I have missed out! In fact, I would be very interested to know what he and others think I have left out or distorted. So do feel free to look at the site and then add a comment with your own reactions.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Hi Paul,
thanks for the write-up, and the invitation to comment on it. I think the key aspect I'd add here is that we need to draw an important distinction between informational and industrial production/produsage in this discussion: produsage, at least at present, operates almost exclusively in the informational realm, where the preconditions (probabilistic approaches, equipotential involvement, granularity of tasks, and shared content) are most likely to be met. So, it would be entirely possible to continue to engage with physical, material goods in a conventional consumeristic fashion, while dealing with informational commodities through produsage.
So, I wouldn't want to make the claim that produsage is going to replace conventional production/consumption right across the board any time soon (even if it is beginning to make some inroads even into the physical realm) - I do think we're moving (in some cases quite rapidly) towards a replacement of production/consumption with produsage in the informational realm, though.
In fact, I'd argue that production and consumption were never terms which applied particularly well to information and knowledge - neither is the process of knowledge-making ever complete (so that it's misleading to speak of 'production' in its core sense), nor do we 'consume' (that is, use up) information in the way that we consume food, natural resources, or even physical goods.
In spite of this, for the last half-century or more we have applied (physical) production concepts to our understanding of and engagement with information, with increasingly unsatisfactory results. Today, we're seeing that alternative approaches are possible - and produsage as a concept is designed to think through these alternatives.
Anyway, thanks for the plug on your site - looking forward to any further comments. In addition to the definition and brief introduction to produsage on my site, your might also be interested in some of the preliminary papers on produsage I've published and presented, which are also available on the site, at http://produsage.org/articles and http://produsage.org/presentations.

item.title: Exploring the Empowerment Agenda
item.dc:creator: Paul Johnston
item.content:encoded: I finally managed to read an excellent document that my good colleague and friend Martin alerted me to - Vern Hughes's paper on the Empowerment Agenda. The paper advocates moving from the current supply-side service delivery model (where citizens are seen as passive recipients) to a model that puts power in the hands of citizens and users. This sounds great, and, although there will obviously be lots of opposition (particularly from established suppliers!), it is definitely the direction we should be heading in. However, it is interesting to explore some of the issues that it raises. Vern's paper focuses on disability and mental health and argues that the users of these services should have pretty much full control of the money spent on helping them - either directly or through consumer brokers. So they (or their agents) should choose what services they want or need and who they obtain them from. One difficult issue this pushes to the fore is quantifying need - every service user would have to have a cash entitlement figure assigned to them. In a way of course this is just making transparent what currently happens (because in principle you could work out the value of service received by each service user or the average for particular types etc). But setting this all out in black and white, so that one kind of disability entitles you to a particular cash figure of support that is 23% more that of another type of disability, will to say the least raise a certain amount of rather lively debate. The difficult choices and comparisons are easier to hide if provision takes the form of appropriate support being provided (with of course scope in particular cases for the support not being quite as appropriate as ideally one might like). My reference to "appropriate" support raises another issue, which is the fear that user groups will use money inappropriately. To use the sort of example that opponents would no doubt leap on, what if someone decides to blow their annual allocation of support on a Carribean holiday, arguing that this is what would make the best contribution to their quality of life or best help improve their condition? What if parent-carers makes this decision on the behalf of the person they are caring for and of course have to accompany this person? This is an extreme example, but it is likely to encourage some to argue for allowing user-held budgets but then adding a vast body of rules that specify exactly what kinds of things budget-holders can spend money on. And yet this kind of top-down, bureaucratic regulation is clearly what Vern wants to get away from. So do we have to go the whole hog and give total freedom to budget holders or are there sensible ways of putting some kind of framework in place that allows freedom without permitting exercises of that freedom that would offend the broad mass of citizens who as taxpayers ultimately fund the provision? This would suggest that the emphasis on accountability to service users needs somehow to be balanced by accountability to the taxpayer. Maybe in current systems both types of accountability are poor, but undoubtedly part of the attraction of supply-side delivery models is that the government (on the taxpayer's behalf) has lots of control of what support gets given. So the change would be moving from a model of "society/the state give support to certain groups but society/the state decide exactly what that support is" to a model of "we collectively assign a cash entitlement figure to every category of person who needs support and anyone who can demonstrate that they belong to that category is free to do whatever they want with that entitlement". That may still sound like a good shift, but even if the contrast is exaggerated, it does (I think) bring out some of the more difficult aspects of the shift. For completeness I will just mention a couple of other obstacles that struck me. First, there are some cost of delivery issues (e.g. the cost of the consumer brokers mentioned above, fragmentation of service provision and loss of economies of scale etc). But this argument strikes me as increasingly irrelevant, since in a connected world the costs and the lost opportunities should be minimal. Second, there are issues about risk-taking and safety nets. To some extent this is a variant on the appropriate use issue, but what happens if a service user opts for a high cost, intensive service in the hope that this will dramatically reduce subsequent needs and then this hope is disappointed? Is there a basic level of service entitlement that cuts back in if someone's budget is exhausted (perhaps for reasons reflecting quite reasonable choices on their part)? Finally, there is the thought that the people who get helped most by this kind of shift are the financially better off. I suppose in part this reflects the fact that direct provision is a form of rationing, i.e. some kind of service is provided and those who can afford a better service opt out and pay for that service themselves. In a more cash-entitlement based world the assumption would be that pretty much everyone would take up their entitlement (so either the overall cost of provision goes up or the less well enough get less provision). So a few thoughts on the difficulties of empowerment and perhaps a clear sign that I have not yet managed to fully shake off my civil servant, supplier-side mentality. But at least my use of a split infinitive in the previous sentence shows I am trying! Interested to know what others think.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
While I can generally get behind the overarching notion of empowering users of state-supported services, the question of which services this might encompass must pass real and meaningful tests associated with reasonableness, eligibility, measurable results and value for money.
Particularly in the case of disability and mental health, how does the creation of a voucher system not create more bureaucracy rather than less? Would the services already being delivered need to be compromised in order to fund such added administration? Most importantly, how would this kind of so-called empowerment enhance the outcomes for those who use such services? Without answering these questions, particularly the last, this paper is long on ideology and short on addressing the specific and very real challenges associated with what the World Health Orhganization has called "an unheralded global crisis in mental health".
Mental illness is the single leading cause of human disability in the world yet it receives a fraction of research and state funding. In Australia, as in many countries, it accounts for a single-digit percentage of the health budget.
This kind of underfunding (and Australia is by no means alone) has only exacerbated the toll in human life and suffering; mental illness kills and not just by suicide, (90% of which have diagnosable mental illnesses) but also its often co-occurence with heart disease and other chronic ailments for example. 95% of homeless people are estimated to have some form of mental illness. In the order of 75% of all short and long term disability claims are related to mental illness One has to ask what positive impact this particular agenda could have on any of this.
It's an interesting choice for the author to single this particular area out as one which would somehow benefit from the regime he posits...as the author notes, the politcal opposition is far more potent elsewhere in the health system, so that may be a clue... perhaps the answer to who might become the "consumer intermediaries" central to the approach might be another.
I imagine you've guessed by now that I'm not sold on this approach as one which supports the ideals and aspirations of either "empowerment" or of "the connected republic".

Just to push back a little... 1 I appreciate that blind faith in human nature can be dangerous, but to assume that people with mental illness or their carers will rush off to the Caribbean instead of using the resources to help their condition is a little unfair (even if it's possible to find some examples, as you would in pretty much any public welfare program I guess). I appreciate that good policy making has to consider the outlier problems, but to use that kind of extreme 'what if' as an argument against the basic proposal is maybe a bit tough. 2 Vouchers of course are the traditional answer to Paul's criticism that people who recieve public funding for particular conditions will abuse the system and waste the resources. But Terry is right that vouchers bring with them a bureaucracy of their own,. So the issue here is, at least in part, if you have to have a bureaucracy, isn't it better that as far as possible it is used to administer a system in which consumers or their representatives have much greater power and authority over what happens to them? I think that's the essence of Vern's thesis. 3 As a general rule, I'm more comfortable with the proposition that those with needs we're trying to help are better judges of what will be in their best interests that relatively distant and disinterested bureaucrats, no matter how well you write the guidelines. That's not to say that such people (as with the rest of us) don't sometimes make decisions that clearly are not in our best interests (drink too much, take drugs, work too hard etc), but over the long haul we tend to be the best judges. It might be a little naive, romantic even, but my problem is the consequences of not accepting that premise. 4 Of course, a true liberal might suggest that both direct funding and vouchers are simply alternative forms of 'churn', in which we tax people and then hand them back their money through programs and services around which we have to write all sorts of complex, cumbersome rules and in the process of which we inevitably create all sorts of systemic frictions which mean we waste money, time and energy to get the job done. The simplest way to fix that is to take less tax off them in the first place and allow them to spend their own money in ways best calculated to advance their interests - pretty much like most of the rest of us in most of the rest of our lives. 5 Terry is spot on about the chronic underfunding of mental health. Vern Hughes is driven by very much that concern, as well as some personal encounters, through some family issues in the mental health field, with the current supply-side system of service design and delivery. His motivation is much the same as Terry's I suspect - not so much ideological as an attempt to open up the debate about possible solutions borne primarily of personal frustration with the status quo. 6 Leaving aside whether you agree with ithe specifics of his proposal, I would have thought that Vern's instincts in search of a different moel are very much in tune with TCR:2 - empower the edge? The power of us? My take on his paper was that here was one attempt to put those principles into action and use them as part of a new approach to service design. 7 I also think the paper is very Web:2 in iits values - co-production, much greater opportunity for consumers to influence the design and delivery of services etc etc.

I certainly share Martin's view that the idea that people will take off to the Caribbean, rather than use funds for their intended purpose is an unfair characterization, though I understand the intent of Paul's statement.
There is no such thing as a 100% elimination of abuse, no matter what model we may be speaking of. There are however, many ways in which elgibility can be better and more consistently determined and to me, that's where this has to start.
To be sure, I disagree with the target audience being chosen, as it represent a group of citizens, stakeholders, constituents who are in a societally vulnerable and exposed place. It's further compounded by the underfunding that's been discussed and of course, this creates a different political dynamic (the lack of political oppostion that the paper refers to, reflects much, including lack of cash).
Notwithstanding all of this, is this a good example of TCR2? I continue to think not. The only way in which the power of us and the empowering of the edge can truly happen is to have a strong centre, supported by political and bureaucratic leadership, appropriate funding, controls and value for money analyses. it may seem paradoxical but without a pragmatic view to "empowering the core", politcal footballs such as this will only cause dismay and disenchantment, not to mention having the potential to actually reduce the quality of service and outcome for those who are most in need. Choosing the wrong group at this juncture will ultimately prove to the naysayers that this kind of thing (the ideals of TCR2 and the embracing of Web2.0) can't work in the public context.

item.title: Government 2.0 - Fad or Future?
item.dc:creator: Paul Johnston
item.content:encoded: Martin has already blogged on the specialist session we did recently on Government 2.0, but I thought people might be interested to hear some of the excellent debate for themselves. So we have now put short podcasts of the opening presentations on the public services summit event website. What was fascinating about the session (and the podcasts) is how each presenter approached the issue in their own way with a slightly different perspective on what the greatest potential benefits of Web 2.o for the public sector were. Geoff Mulgan was really interested in the scope for innovation at the edge and around public sector organisations; Hugh McPhail was excited by the potential for opening up government through greater transparency; while Joanne Caddy focussed on the issue of participation. It was also interesting to see the different takes on the obstacles to Government 2.0. Here I thought that Tom Bentley's contribution was particularly interesting with his analysis of the three forces holding back Web 2.0 type approaches - secrecy, silos and surprise. So a fascinating set of views that I hope people will enjoy and certainly a set of issues that we are likely to keep coming back to in the different parts of this site. PS If you explore the rest of the site, you may notice that we are doing a bit of a revamp in order to encourage more user participation. Do feel free to get involved or to make comments on how the site could be improved. Further changes coming in the next two weeks.

item.title: The Realism of the Web
item.dc:creator: Paul Johnston
item.content:encoded: There have been quite a few posts on this blog about the Public Services Summit last December, but for me the highlight of the event was David Weinberger’s inspirational presentation The Realism of the Web. How can you not love a guy who begins his talk by saying that he does not think the web has been hyped enough? It’s a fantastic presentation and captures some really important things about how the Web opens up new possibilities and changes the way we need to think about things. David focuses on three aspects of the Web - generosity, intimacy, and (acceptance of) fallibility - and celebrates them as enabling more truly human forms of interaction. He emphasizes how knowledge emerges from conversation (rather than meditation) and how peer-to-peer collaboration can be at least as productive as top-down organisation. Of course, there is still a role for meditation and for organisation, but the excitement of the connected world is the phenomenally expanded role for conversation and collaboration. As David's talk makes abundantly clear, the danger is not that we will over-estimate the impact of the web but that we become blase about it. Every now and then we need to listen to someone like David and remind ourselves just how exciting the possibilities are! The presentation is available (100 mega file) on the event website, but I have also put it on YouTube - broken down (as YouTube requires) into ten-minute bites. I hope you enjoy it as much as I do.
